introduction.p:
We found above that angular momentum of a body rotating with angular velocity \omega about a principal axis is
L = I\,\omega,
where I is the moment of inertia of the body about the axis of rotation. If you compare this formula with the formula for the magnitude of momentum of a particle of mass m and velocity \vec v .
p = m v,
you will notice that moment of inertia I plays the same role in rotation as mass m plays in the translational motion.

When we studied \vec F = m\vec a for constant mass system, we found that mass m can be interpreted as a measure of inertia against change in velocity. Later in this chapter, when we introduce a similar dynamic equation, \tau = I \alpha for constant I system, where \tau is torque of the force, we will find that I is a measure of inertia against change in angular velocity, and hence the name, moment of inertia.
In this section, we will practice computing moment of inertia of some commonly encountered objects, starting from the fundamental formula for the moment of inertia of a single particle.

subsection.title: Moment of Inertia of Single Particle

sidebyside.p:
Consider a single particle of mass m moving in a circle of radius R as shown in . We can think of it as a particle rotating about an axis at a distance R from the axis. The moment of inertia of this system is
I_{\text{particle}} = m\,R^2.
This will be the building block for moment of inertia of an arbitrary object.

subsection.title: Moment of Inertia of Systems of Particles

sidebyside.p: Suppose we have N particles that rotate about a common axis as shown in . The figure shows a system of 4 particles. Let m_1, m_2, \cdots, be their masses and R_1, R_2, \cdots, be their distances from the axis. The net moment of inertia will be the sum of moment of inertia for each particle.

subsection.men: I_{N\text{-particles}} = m_1 R_1^2 + m_2 R_2^2 + \cdots + m_N R_N^2.
subsection.p: We might write this using a sum notation.

example.title: Moment of Inertia of a Baton about an Irregular Axis

sidebyside.p: A 1.2\text{-m} baton has a 0.4\text{-kg} ball at each end. The rod of the baton has considerably smaller mass which we can ignore in this problem. The baton is held at 0.5\text{ m} from one end and twirled so that the two masses rotate about a vertical axis at an angle of 30^{\circ} from the axis.

statement.p: (a) Find the distances of the two masses from the axis of rotation.
(b) Find the moment of inertia of the baton about the axis described in the problem.

sidebyside.p:
We figure out the distances from the radii of the circles in which the balls move. We do that by dropping a perpendicular from the masses to the axis and using trig on the triangle formed.
\amp R_1 = l_1\,\sin\,30^{\circ} = \dfrac{0.7}{2} = 0.35\text{ m}. \amp R_2 = l_2\,\sin\,30^{\circ} = \dfrac{0.5}{2} = 0.25\text{ m}.

solution.title: b
solution.p:
From the masses and the distances from the axis, we get
I = m_1 R_1^2 + m_2 R_2^2 = 0.4\times(0.35^2 + 0.25^2) = 0.074\text{ kg.m}^2.

example.title: Moment of Inertia and Angular Momentum of a Three Particle System

sidebyside.p: Three particles of masses m_1, m_2, and m_3 are rotating with angular speed \omega about the given axis shown in . Find the magnitude and direction of the total angular momentum in two different ways: (a) from a sum of the angular momentum of each particle, and (b) first finding the moment of inertia of the three as a system about the axis of rotation, and then multiplying the moment of inertia about the axis with the angular velocity about that axis.

Each particle has angular momentum l = mvr where r is the radius of its circle of motion. Speed of its motion will be v = \omega r . Therefore, we will get
\amp l_1 = 0,\ \text{ since } r_1 = 0. \amp l_2 = m_2\, \left( \omega\, a\,\sin\theta \right)\, a\,\sin\theta ,\ \text{ since } r_2 = a\,\sin\theta. \amp l_3 = 0,\ \text{ since } r_3 = 0.
Using the right-hand rule, we get the direction of \vec l_2 to be up. Therefore, the total angular momentum is m_2\, \omega\, a^2\,\sin^2\theta, pointed up.

solution.title: b
solution.p:
The moment of inertia of a point particle is mr^2 where r is the radius of its circle of motion. From the radii found in (a), we can immediately write the moment of inertia to be
I = 0 + m_2\, a^2\,\sin^2\theta + 0.
Therefore, the magnitude of angular momentum will be I\omega, which is the same as we found in (a). The direction is found by applying the right-hand rule, which gives the direction up.

example.title: Moment of Inertia and Angular Momentum of a Three Particle System Different Axis

sidebyside.p:
Three particles of masses m_1, m_2, and m_3 are rotating with angular speed \omega about the given axis shown in the figure. Find the magnitude and direction of the total angular momentum in two different ways:
(a) from a sum of the angular momentum of each particle, and
(b) first finding the moment of inertia of the three as a system about the axis of rotation, and then multiplying the moment of inertia about the axis with the angular velocity about that axis.

answer.p: (a) \frac{\omega\, a^2}{\cos^2\theta}\, \left( m_1\, \sin^4\theta + m_3\,\cos^4\theta \right), to the right. (b) Same as (a).

solution.title: a

sidebyside.p:
First, we figure out the radii of the circles of the motion of each particle. The figure is helpful in that.
\amp r_1 = a\,\sin^2\,\theta/\cos\,\theta, \amp l=r_2 = 0, \amp r_3 = a\,\cos\,\theta.

solution.p: Each particle has angular momentum l = mvr where r is the radius of its circle of motion. Speed of its motion will be v = \omega r , where \omega is same for all particles.

Therefore, we will get
\amp l_1 = m_1\,\omega\, \left( a\,\sin^2\,\theta/\cos\,\theta \right)^2, \amp l_2 = 0, \amp l_3 = m_3\,\omega\, \left( a\,\cos\,\theta \right)^2.
Both l_1 and l_3 are pointed in the same direction, to the direction right. Therefore, they will add, giving us the magntitude of the net angular momentum to be
L = \omega\, a^2\, \left( m_1\, \sin^4\theta/\cos^2\theta + m_3\,\cos^2\theta \right).

solution.title: b
solution.p:
The moment of inertia of a point particle is mr^2 where r is the radius of its circle of motion. From the radii found in (a), we can immediately write the moment of inertia to be
I = m_1\, a^2\,\sin^4\theta/\cos^2\theta + 0 + m_3\,a^2\,\cos^2\theta.
Therefore, the magnitude of angular momentum will be I\omega, which is the same as we found in (a). The direction is found by applying the right-hand rule, which gives the direction right.

subsection.title: Moment of Inertia of a Uniform Rod

sidebyside.p: We look at the simplest continuous mass system - a rod of length L and mass M, rotating about an axis that passes through one edge perpendicular to the rod as shown in the figure.

subsection.p: If we divide up the rod into N parts, we can essentially turn the rod into N-particle system as shown in .

figure.caption: We divide up the rod into N (shown 7) equal cells and place the masses in each piece at one end of each cell. We can then use the formula for the moment of inertia of each mass to estimate the moment of inertia of the rod.

subsection.p:
For simplicity, let us take the segments to be of equal length \Delta r,
\Delta r = \dfrac{L}{N}.
We now place the masses in each segment at the right end of the segments. This gives us the distance R_i to the i-th mass as follows,
R_i = i\Delta r,
with mass in each segment
m_i = \dfrac{M}{N}.
This will result in the following formula for the moment of inertia.
I = \sum_{i=}^{N}m_i R_i^2 = \dfrac{M (\Delta r)^2 }{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\, i^2.
The sum the squares of integers is known to be
\sum_{i=1}^{N}\, i^2 = \dfrac{N (N + 1) (2N + 1)}{6}.
Therefore, dividing up the rod in N equal parts gives us the following formula for the moment of inertia of the rod.
I = \dfrac{M (\Delta r)^2 }{N} \times \dfrac{N (N + 1) (2N + 1)}{6}.
Cancelling N from numerator and denominator simplifies this to
I = \dfrac{1}{6}\, M (\Delta r)^2 (N + 1) (2N + 1).
Now, the original rod had many particles; in an ordinary sized rod, N would be of the order of Avogadro number, N_A = 6 \times 10^{23}. That will make adding 1 to N or to 2N insignificant. Thus,
I = \dfrac{1}{6}\, M (\Delta r)^2 \times 2N^2 = \dfrac{1}{3} M (N\Delta r)^2.
Using N\Delta r = L, the length of the rod, we finally get the formula for moment inertia of a rod about an axis through one end.
I_{\text{rod}}^{\text{axis-at-end}} = \dfrac{1}{3}\, M L^2.

example.title: A Chain of Rings Rotating About an Axis Through One End

sidebyside.p: N rings, each of mass m, are linked together into a chain and hung from the middle. The chain is then rotated at an angular speed of \omega such that the angle with the vertical is \theta as shown in the figure. Model the chain as a sequence of masses separated by distance a , and find the magnitude and direction of angular momentum.

hint.p: Use L=I\omega. Find I by adding up the I of each ring. You may fin dit helpful to focus on an arbitrary i-th ring.

solution.p:
Let r_i be the radius of the circle in which the i-th ring rotates. The distance of this ring from the support is ia. Therefore, the moment of inertia of this ring is
I_i = mr_i^2 = m \left( i a \sin\,\theta\right)^2 = \left( m a^2 \sin^2\theta\right)\, i^2.
Summing these for all N rings gives
I \amp = \sum I_i = \left( m a^2 \sin^2\theta\right)\, \sum_{i=1}^{N} i^2 \amp = \left( m a^2 \sin^2\theta\right)\, \dfrac{N(N+1)(2N+1)}{6}.
Therefore, the magnitude of angular momentum will be
L = I\omega = \left( m a^2 \sin^2\theta\right)\, \dfrac{N(N+1)(2N+1)}{6}\, \omega.
By using the right-hand rule, the direction of \vec L is up.

subsection.title: The Parallel-Axis Theorem
subsection.p: The parallel-axis theorem establishes a relation between the moment of inertia about an axis through the center of mass and about another axis that is parallel to this axis. We will state it here and prove in the Calculus-based section.

sidebyside.p:
Let M be the mass of the object, I_{\text{cm}} be the moment of inertia about an axis through the center of mass and I_{\text{A}} be the moment of inertia about a parallel axis that is a distance d away. Then,
I_{\text{A}} = I_{\text{cm}} + M\,d^2.

example.title: Moment of Inertia Through the CM of a Rod

statement.p:
The moment of inertial of a rod of length L and mass M about an axis through one edge and perpendicular to the rod is given by
I_{\text{edge}} = \dfrac{1}{3}ML^2.
Find the moment of inertia of the rod about an axis through the center of the rod and perpendicular to the rod.

solution.p:
Using the parallel axis theorem, we can write the following relation.
I_{\text{edge}} = I_{\text{cm}} + M\,\left( \dfrac{L}{2} \right)^2
Using the formula, I_{\text{edge}} = \dfrac{1}{3}ML^2, given to us, we get
I_{\text{cm}} = \left( \dfrac{1}{3} - \dfrac{1}{4} \right)\, ML^2 = \dfrac{1}{12}\,ML^2.

subsection.title: Radius of Gyration
subsection.p: We ask the following question: suppose we replace a rotating body of mass M by a point particle of the same mass M, at what distance should we place this fictitious particle so that its moment of inertia will be the same as that of the original body? This distance is called the radius of gyration , which is denoted by R_G.

For instance, the moment of inertia of a disk of mass M and radius R about an axis through the center and perpendicular to the disk is
I_{\text{disk}}^{\perp} = \dfrac{1}{2} MR^2.
Replacing the disk by a point mass R_G away from the axis will mean
I_\text{particle} = M R_G^2 = \dfrac{1}{2} MR^2 = I_{\text{disk}}^{\perp}, which gives
R_G = \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\,R.
This is not the only R_G in a disk. If we rotate the disk about an axis through the center but the axis is in the plane of the face of the disk, then, we will have M R_G^2 = \dfrac{1}{4} MR^2, giving
R_G = \dfrac{1}{2}\,R.
Thus, there is not one R_G per object, but one R_G per axis, unless the object is fully symmetric, such as a sphere. In that case there is only one R_G, which is
R_G^{\text{sphere}} = \dfrac{\sqrt{2}}{\sqrt{5}}\, R,
since moment of inertia of a sphere through any axis through its center is
I_{\text{sphere}} = \dfrac{2}{5}\,MR^2.

subsection.title: (Calculus) Moment of Inertia of a Uniform Rod
subsection.p: The non-Calculus derivation of the moment of inertia of a rod about its end done above is difficult to generalize to more complicated objects, such as disk. Here, we introduce the Calculus aproach to the same problem.

sidebyside.p: We start with noting that moment of inertia will be the sum of moment onertia of all the particles of the rod. Let us look at the infinitesimal mass \delta m that is between r and r + dr from the end of the rod.

subsection.p:
Assuming mass is distributed uniformly over the length of the rod, we can immediately write the value of \delta m.
\delta m = \dfrac{M}{L}\, dr.

Since this is at a distance r from the axis, its moment of inertia is
\delta I = r^2 \delta m = \dfrac{M}{L}\, r^2 dr.
Adding the contributions of all the particles can be achieved by integrating this from r = 0 to r = L, giving the following for the moment of inertia of the rod.
I = \int_0^L\, \dfrac{M}{L}\, r^2 dr = \dfrac{M}{L}\times \dfrac{L^3}{3}.
Simplifying this gives us the same answer we found above.
I_{\text{rod}}^{\text{axis-at-end}} = \dfrac{1}{3}\, M L^2.

subsection.title: (Calculus) Proof of the Parallel Axis Theorem
subsection.p:
Let us choose the z axis to be the orientation of the two parallel axes, one through the CM and the other through the axis A as shown in . Let origin be at the CM, which would mean
\int x dm = 0,\ \ \int y dm = 0, \ \ \int z dm = 0.
The moment of inertia about axis through the CM will be
I_{\text{cm}} = \int \left( x^2 + y^2 \right)\, dm.

figure.caption: The diagram for parallel axis theorem proof. For clarity, the y axis has been supressed and we have drawn x axis in the direction from P to the CM.

subsection.p:
If axis A intersects the plane (perpendicular to the axes that contains the CM) at point P with cooridinates (x_P, y_P, 0) with respect to the coordinate system with origin at the CM, then
x_P^2 + y_P^2 = d^2.
With another coordinate system, say Px'y'z' with origin at P, we get the moment of inertial expression for I_{\text{A}} .
I_{\text{A}} = \int \left( x'^2 + y'^2 \right)\, dm',
with
x' = x-x_P,\ y' = y-y_P,\ z' = z,\ dm'=dm.
Substituting this in I_{\text{A}} we get
I_{\text{A}} \amp = \int \left( (x-x_P)^2 + (y-y_P)^2 \right)\, dm, \amp = \int \left( x^2 + y^2 \right)\, dm - 2x_P\int xdm - 2y_P\int ydm + d^2\int dm, \amp = I_{\text{cm}} + 0 + 0 + Md^2.
Therefore,
I_{\text{A}} = I_{\text{cm}} + Md^2.

subsection.title: (Calculus) Moment of Inertia of a Uniform Body
subsection.p:
The method illustrated above for the moment of inertia of a rod, can be generalized for any uniform body. Let \delta m be an infinitesimal mass element whose distance from the axis is r , then its contribution to moment of inertia will be
\delta I = r^2 \delta m.

We are using the notation \delta m for an infinitesimal mass rather than dm since we usually do not do an integral over this variable, but rather use it to think about the problem, and replace \delta m by one of the infinitesimal expressions given below, and then perform appropriate integral.
I = \int\, r^2 \delta m.

subsection.title: (Calculus) Principal Axes and Moment of Inertia Tensor
subsection.p: If a body has a rotational symmetry, we can direct the Cartesian axes to take advantage of that symmetry and simplify the expressions of moment of inertia.

What happens if rotating body does not have a rotational symmetry? Turns out that every rigid body, regardless of shape, has three mutually perpendicular special directions in space, called principal axes. The moment of inertia about these principal axes are called principal moments.

Suppose we choose Cartesian axes along the principal axes, and call the moments of inertia about them to be I_{xx}, I_{yy}, and I_{zz}. Then, the angular momentum vector for any arbitrary rotation with \omega = (\omega_x,\ \omega_y,\ \omega_z) will have the following components.
\amp L_x = I_{xx}\omega_x, \amp L_y = I_{yy}\omega_y, \amp L_z = I_{xx}\omega_z.

In a general situation, if you are not using principal axes for your Cartesian coordinates, then, you would find that a component of the angular momentum, say L_x depends on all three components of \vec \omega.
L_x = I_{xx}\omega_x + I_{xy}\omega_y + I_{xz}\omega_z,
where coefficients I_{xy} and I_{xz} of \omega_y and \omega_z, respectivley, are also moments of inertia, called the off-diagonal elements of the moment of inertia tensor. Their formulas are different than the diagonal elements. Similarly, for L_y and L_z. For a curious student, the formulas for various moments of inertia are listed here.
\amp I_{xx} = \int\, (y^2 + z^2)\, dm, \amp I_{yy} = \int\, (z^2 + x^2)\, dm, \amp I_{zz} = \int\, (x^2 + y^2)\, dm, \amp I_{xy} = I_{yx} = -\int\, x\,y\, dm , \amp I_{yz} = I_{zy} = -\int\, y\,z\, dm , \amp I_{zx} = I_{xz} = -\int\, z\,x\, dm .

exercise.title: Moment of Inertia of a Disk with a Hole in the Center - Negative Mass Trick

sidebyside.p: You cut out a circular hole of radius b from a disk of radius a and mass M. What is the moment of inertia of the resulting disk with the hole about an axis perpendicular to the disk and passing through the center? Assuming uniform density.

hint.p: Think of hole as another disk with negative mass density.

solution.p:
Let \rho be the density and h the thickness.
\rho = \dfrac{M}{\pi a^2 h}.
Now, we think of the disk with the hole as a complete disk of radius a and density \rho and a second disk of radius b but of density -\rho. This way of treating hole in a material is called the negative mass trick. The moments of inertia of these two disks will be
I_a \amp = \dfrac{1}{2} M_a a^2 = \dfrac{1}{2} M a^2, I_b \amp = \dfrac{1}{2} M_b b^2 = -\dfrac{1}{2} \pi b^2 h \rho b^2.
We can write I_b in terms of M as follows
I_b = -\dfrac{1}{2} M \dfrac{b^4}{a^2}.
Adding the two moments we get
I = I_a + I_b = \dfrac{1}{2} M a^2 \left( 1 - \dfrac{b^4}{a^4} \right).

exercise.title: Moment of Inertia of a Disk with Off-Axis Hole - Negative Mass Trick

sidebyside.p: You cut out a circular hole of radius b from a disk of radius a and mass M. The center of the hole is at a distance c from the axis of rotation, which is perpendicular to the disk and passes through the center. What is the moment of inertia of the resulting disk about the axis through the center? Assuming uniform density.

hint.p: Think of hole as another disk with negative mass density and use parallel axis theorem.

solution.p: First we fill the hole with negative density material to get a complete disk. Thus, replacing the disk with a hole by two complete disks, one of mass M and radius a and another of mass -M b^2/a^2 and radius b, but rotating with axis to center distance c.

The moment of inertia of the off-axis disk can be obtained by applying the parallel axis theorem. Thus, the moments of inertia of the two disks are
I_a \amp = \dfrac{1}{2} M a^2 I_b \amp = -\dfrac{1}{2} M \dfrac{b^2}{a^2} b^2 - M \dfrac{b^2}{a^2} c^2
Therefore, the moment of inertial of the disk with the hole is
I = I_a + I_b = \dfrac{1}{2} M a^2 \left( 1 - \dfrac{b^2(b^2 + 2c^2)}{a^4} \right).

exercise.title: (Calculus) Moment of Inertia of Rod about Axis Through the Center

statement.p: Derive the expression for the moment of inertia of a uniform rod of mass M and length L about an axis through its center and perpendicular to the rod.

hint.p: Set up moment of inertial of an element at x away from axis.

solution.p:
shows the setup for the calculaton. We place the rod symmetrically on the xaxis. Looking at the moment of inertia of a segment at distance x from the axis we note that the moment of inertial of \delta m in the segment will be
\delta I = \delta m\, x^2 = (M/L)dx\, x^2.

Integrating this from x=-L/2 to x=L/2 will give the answer we seek.
I \amp = (M/L)\int_{-L/2}^{L/2}\, x^2 dx = 2(M/L)\int_{0}^{L/2}\, x^2 dx, \amp = \dfrac{2M}{L}\, \dfrac{1}{3}\,\left( \dfrac{L}{2}\right)^3 = \dfrac{1}{12}\,ML^2.

exercise.title: (Calculus) Moment of Inertia of Triangular Plate about an Axis Through the Corner

statement.p: Derive the expression for the moment of inertia of a uniform right-angled triangle of mass M, base b, and height h about an axis through the corner of base and hypoteneus and parallel to the height side.

hint.p: Place axes with origin at the corner through which axis passes and x axis along the base. Set up moment of inertia of an element at x away from axis.

solution.p: shows the setup for the calculaton. We place origin at the corner through which axis passes and point x axis along the base. The axis of rotation is the y axis.

Now, we look at element of width dx and height y at a distance x from the axis. Its moment of inertia is
\delta I = \delta m\, x^2 = \left( \dfrac{M}{A}\, ydx \right)\, x^2,
where A = (1/2)bh, the area of the triangle. Here y = (h/b) x. Therefore, we have for the moment of inertia of the element as
\delta I = \dfrac{Mh}{Ab} \, x^3 dx.
Integrating from x=0 to x=b will give us the answer.
I \amp = \dfrac{Mh}{Ab} \, \int_0^b\, x^3 dx = \dfrac{Mh}{Ab}\times \dfrac{b^4}{4}.
We can simplify it
\dfrac{2Mh}{bhb}\times \dfrac{b^4}{4} = \dfrac{1}{2} M b^2.

exercise.title: (Calculus) Moment of Inertia of Right Triangular Plate About one Edge

statement.p: Derive the expression for the moment of inertia of a uniform right-angled triangle of mass M, base b, and height h about an axis coincident with the height side.

hint.p: Choose y axis to be axis of rotation. Set up moment of inertia of an element at x away from axis.

solution.p: shows the setup for the calculaton. We place origin at the corner of right-angle. With axis of rotation to be the y axis, we have base along x axis.

Now, we look at element of width dx and height y at a distance x from the axis. Its moment of inertia is
\delta I = \delta m\, x^2 = \left( \dfrac{M}{A}\, ydx \right)\, x^2,
where A = (1/2)bh, the area of the triangle. Here y = h - (h/b) x. Therefore, we have for the moment of inertia of the element as
\delta I = \dfrac{M}{A} \, \left( h x^2 -(h/b) x^3 \right) dx.
Integrating from x=0 to x=b will give us the answer.
I \amp = \dfrac{M}{A} \times \dfrac{hb^3}{12} = \dfrac{1}{6}Mb^2.

exercise.title: (Calculus) Moment of Inertia of Thin Disk about an Axis Through the Center and Perpendicular to Disk

statement.p: Derive the expression for the moment of inertia of a uniform thin disk of mass M and radius R about an axis through the center and perpendicular to the disk.

hint.p: Think of a disk being made up of rings. A ring has all masses same distance from the center. Therefore, moment of inertia of ring will be m r^2. You need to think of how to add them.

exercise.solution:
shows setup for claculations. The axis in coming-out-of page in the figure.
Figure for solutiuon.
Now we look at an element of the disk in the shape of a ring between r and r+dr. All masses in the ring would rotated from the axis at a distance r. Therefore, moment of inertia of the ring element will be
\delta I = \delta m \times r^2 = \left( \dfrac{M}{A}\, 2\pi r dr \right)\, r^2,
where A=\pi R^2 and 2\pi r dr is the area of the ring. We would integrate this from r=0 to r=R to find I.
I \amp = \dfrac{2M}{R^2}\, \int_0^R r^3 dr = \dfrac{1}{2}\,MR^2.

exercise.title: (Calculus) Moment of Inertia of Thin Disk about an Axis Through the Center and Coplanar to Disk

statement.p: Derive the expression for the moment of inertia of a uniform thin disk of mass M and radius R about an axis through the center and coplanar to the disk, i,e., along one of its diameter.

hint.p: Take y axis to be axis of rotation and an element between x anx x+dx parallel to y axis.

exercise.solution:
shows setup for claculations. The axis is along y axis.
Figure for solutiuon.
Now we look at an element of the disk in rectangular shape between x and x+dx. The area of the element will be 2ydx since the length is 2y and width dx. The y in the element area is
y = \sqrt{R^2 - x^2}.
All masses in the element would rotated from the axis at a distance x. Therefore, moment of inertia of the ring element will be
\delta I \amp = \delta m \times x^2 = \left( \dfrac{M}{A}\, 2ydx \right)\, x^2, \amp = \dfrac{2M}{\pi R^2}\, x^2 \sqrt{R^2 - x^2}\, dx
We would integrate this from x=-R to r=R to find I. Since integrand is an even function of x. That would mean we will get 2 times integral from x=0 to r=R.
I \amp = \dfrac{2M}{\pi R^2}\,2\times\,\int_0^R x^2 \sqrt{R^2 - x^2}\, dx.
The integral is difficult to do. I typed the command integrate x^2*sqrt(R^2-x^2), x in https://www.wolframalpha.com/ and found the following answer.
\int_0^R x^2 \sqrt{R^2 - x^2}\, dx \amp = \dfrac{1}{8}\left[ x\sqrt{R^2 - x^2}\left( 2x^2 - R^2\right) \right. \amp \ \ + R^4\tan^{-1}\left.\left( \dfrac{x}{R^2-x^2}\right)\right]_0^R, \amp = \dfrac{1}{8}\left[ 0 - 0 + \dfrac{\pi}{2} - 0\right] = \dfrac{\pi}{16}.
Therefore,
I = \dfrac{4M}{\pi R^2} \times \dfrac{\pi}{16} = \dfrac{1}{4}\,MR^2.

exercise.title: (Calculus) Moment of Inertia of a Sphere about an Axis Through the Center

statement.p: Derive the expression for the moment of inertia of a uniform sphere of mass M and radius R about an axis through the center of the sphere.

hint.p: With z axis as axis of rotation, consider thin disk between z and z+dz.

solution.p: shows setup for claculations. The axis of rotation is z axis in the figure.

Now we look at an element of the sphere in the shape of a disk perpendicular to z axis between z and z+dz. The radius of the disk r is
r = \sqrt{R^2 - z^2}.
Therefore, volume of the element is
dV = \pi r^2 dz =\pi\, \left(R^2 - z^2 \right)\, dz.
The mass of the disk is
dm = \dfrac{M}{V}\, dV = \dfrac{M}{V}\, \pi\, \left(R^2 - z^2 \right)\, dz,
where V = \frac{4}{3}\pi R^3. The moment of inertia of this element about z axis is
dI = \dfrac{1}{2}\, dm\, r^2.
This gives
dI = \dfrac{M}{2V}\, \pi\, \left(R^2 - z^2 \right)^2\, dz.
